Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Independent Science Learning through Serious Games with Expert Avatars and Complementary Stories
Award.AbstractNarration:
This STTR Phase I project will develop and test a learning platform to facilitate independent, personal and enjoyable science education. The platform combines an engaging book, whose characters employ a fictional virtual environment to solve a mystery, with a complementary computer-based virtual environment to support games, explorations, and interviews with Expert Avatars (XAs), such as Albert Einstein and Henrietta Leavitt, that appear in the book. The goal is to increase the interest in science for children in grades 5-8, where there is a shortage of science teachers, and where educational tools must compete with the high level of technology to which young people are attracted, like games with talking avatars and virtual personal assistants to answer their questions. Increasing students' interest in science careers can help fill the projected worker shortage for high tech industries and provide desperately needed science teachers. Filling these jobs is expected to increase America's GDP (and tax revenues) and high tech exports. This project will develop the initial offering in a projected series to facilitate independent learning of science, mathematics, engineering, history, the arts and other subjects through interesting stories and exciting virtual environments populated with XAs for the leaders in their fields.

The project will build on the successful application in education of computer-based virtual environments and games by adding two important features. First, the digital content will be complemented by the book, whose characters use a fictional virtual environment to solve the same STARDUST MYSTERY posed in the game. What is STARDUST? Where, when and how did it form? How did it get into George Washington and from him to you? The book provides an introduction, user's guide, scaffolding and sales channel for the game. Second, the virtual environment and game, developed with Unity 3-D, will be populated by XAs for some of the great minds in science. The game will support virtual explorations, such as a trip back through time to the Big Bang and virtual visits with the XAs. The XA's will be backed by an artificial intelligence (AI) system to support a conversation where students' can get answers to questions about the XA's contributions, their lives and their period in history. Responses will be generated using customized knowledge bases for each XA and a hybrid, cloud-based AI system. The project will include a formative evaluation of the game combined with book excerpts to assess the benefits of, and receptivity to, the game, book and XA combination.

POR.DRECONTENT:
"You are made of STARDUST that was once in the body of Albert Einstein and the last T-Rex." That is the true science theme of THE STARDUST MYSTERY game developed to teach children ages 8 to 13 about atoms.  A startling fact is that human beings actually have inherited trillions of carbon atoms once in the body, and exhaled by, every dinosaur, by Einstein, and by every other living thing. Using gaming for learning is based on research indicating that over 90% of the target demographic plays computer games, and that games can be highly effective learning tools.  But learning games have so far not proved popular with children.  Hence, THE STARDUST MYSTERY Game was designed to meet the dual success criteria for both learning and recreational games.  

THE STARDUST MYSTERY game and the complementary book weave the science into exciting adventure stories exploring where the students' own STARDUST has been. Four-player crews cooperate to find out what STARDUST is (atoms), how and when it was created (in the Big Bang and supernovae), how it got into Einstein, and from him to others (the carbon cycle). They are helped in their quest by eXpert Avatars (XAs) like Albert Einstein, who appear in the game to verbally answer spoken questions. Students cooperate in teams and have fun, while learning many NGSS core ideas: atoms as the basic building blocks of our world; atoms' small size and enormous number; atom recycling; the history of Earth, and the history of the Universe.

Under this NSF project, a ten-level, four-player computer game was designed, and the core mechanics of the game prototyped. Players start in the Mystery Museum with dynamic exhibits on the KT extinction event, the Moon formation, plate tectonics, and carbon transfer.  There, they learn their missions, crew responsibilities and tools, and the underlying science.  Next, they cooperate as crew members of the Beamer, a virtual time, space and dimensional travel machine, to explore a human body to discover the part of the body that is STARDUST.  Then, they fly the Beamer to follow the Stardust Trail of inheritance to adventures in past worlds, first visiting XA Albert Einstein in 1955, the Ice Age 0.05 million years ago (0.05 Mya), the Dinosaur KT Extinction Era (65 Mya), Pangaea (300 Mya), Earth Formation (4600 Mya), a first star supernovae (13,500 Mya), and the Big Bang (13,800 Mya). In the game design, Virtual Scientific Instruments such as an elemental composition analyzer, a compass, a carbon inheritance counter, a thermal decomposition probe, and a rock dating tool, are used in player quests.  The Company is striving to create a game that is so much fun and so engaging, that children want to use it on their own for recreation, a game that can compete with successful recreational games like Minecraft and Civilization that now are being adapted for education. 

Game prototypes were created using the Unity 3D game engine for the Mystery Museum, the Beamer, the Einstein XA, and the KT Extinction era environment. The prototype Dino Extinction game won (in a tie) the Kids Vote Award for "Best SBIR Learning Game" at the 2016 Dept. of Education ED Games Expo.  In one of several other positive outcomes, sixth grade students rated the game as 9.2 of 10 as a science game and 9.3 as a recreational game.

The project employs several innovations.  The XAs will answer a student's spoken questions with curated verbal responses, accompanied by text and graphics. The XA's Learning Manager software guides and assesses the student in achieving teacher specified learning goals. The project's companion STARDUST MYSTERY book acts as a game user's guide and alternative presentation of the scientific themes.  The game design employs Virtual Scientific Instruments that provide data on game objects.

            The impact of this technology includes improvement of US science learning through teaching of science themes as exciting stories, presented in both book and game formats that are entertaining and educational. The technology has the ability to improve learning in underperforming schools, can help reverse the decline in the number of Americans pursuing STEM careers, and provide resources to compensate for the lack of certified science teachers in grades 3-8.  The XA and Beamer themes can be expanded to other topics in STEM, history, economics, the arts, law, finance, health, etc.    

Mission KT (formerly Dino Extinction), about adventures on Earth in the KT era world of dinosaurs, is planned for release in both recreational and education editions in Q4 2017.  The educational edition would be played by students at home or in the school computer lab following an in-class video and discussion.  The Company is producing 10 short science videos using captured game footage, narrated by THE STARDUST MYSTERY book characters, that cover topics on atoms, the carbon cycle, the KT extinction and KT Survivors.
